instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2338: What is A2338? A2338 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2020 M1, Mid 2022 M2 with EMC 8162, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02020, 820-02773..
definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S2: What is PP3V3_S2? PP3V3_S2 is a typo of PP3V3_S3.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no image.

Already tried with new display, but same result; no image.

However, I have image on external monitor.

Not sure where to start, but:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL> = 0V and 0.003 on diode reading, and 0.01ohm resistance to ground

<SIGNAL>P3V3S2_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 0V and 0.682 on diode reading

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON_3V3S2_VIN_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 0V and 0.002 on diode reading

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AON</SIGNAL> = 3.287V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL> = 0V

Can the culprit be UC710?

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
After replacing  UC710, now  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL> has 2.350V and still no image...

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON_3V3S2_VIN_ISNS</SIGNAL>  = 2.782V

<SIGNAL>P3V3S2_EN</SIGNAL> = 1.310V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL> = 2.350V

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S2</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S2</SIGNAL> = 5.194V

<SIGNAL>P3V3S2_PGOOD</SIGNAL>  = 0V

Any help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S2</SIGNAL> is still low; that's why its power good signal is not present.

Check RC709-13 and their traces.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
HI,
Tks for the help.

All RC709-13 are ok (normal resistance values), and their traces are also ok.

Just notice that <SIGNAL>P3V3S2_PGOOD</SIGNAL>  starts with 3.261V and then drops to 0V and  <SIGNAL>3V3_S2</SIGNAL>  starts with 3.290V and then drops to  2.350V (after about 15 seconds)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
It should be good enough, if <SIGNAL>3V3_S2</SIGNAL> starts with good voltage.
Enable signal probably comes from 1V8 logic side.
You can compare its level with another power enable coming from same side of <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> (page 33).

UC710 overheats?
You may try to change it again, just in case.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Hi,

While resoldering UC710 again, I notice that a bit of the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON_3V3S2_VIN_ISNS</SIGNAL> board pad was burnt (missing a piece). Howver it has continuity with CC721. Do you think it can be related?

UC710 doesnÂ´t get hot. I don't have any more UC710 and can't find it online; Do you think i can order TPS621351RGXT instead?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Be sure to get correct voltage at pin 1/UC710.
Run wire over the trace, if needed.

Check if  TPS621351RGXT has the same layout.
If yes, you can give it a try.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Hi,

Pin 1/UC710  (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON_3V3S2_VIN_ISNS</SIGNAL> starts at 10V and then drops to 2.782V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is 11.98 steady. Can it be RD560 the culprit?

I presume that was because of  <SIGNAL>3V3_S2</SIGNAL> problem. Shall i address this first?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message: Then you have a problem with RD560, or its traces.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
